text: I got to experience being underneath one of these giant confetti cannons over the weekend. It was totally fun throwing the confetti around after it was done. <http://www.effectspecialist.com/imagesSP/big%20blaster.png>
missing standup today. my status: going to move goldspike cubby into wall and wire up. also going to pick up a canvas dropcloth to hide wall during open house
me too, double booked with wrapping up a preview and being in an adidas meeting. cheers
<!here|@here>: stand up

<@U02F8LF2X>: wahat else are you planning to ‘do’ for wall trying to figure out whats you/peter joel list includes:
- dialing the lighting
- dialing the motor
- programming the integrated touch screen
motor should be reconfigured to be part of our network... it's a static default address of 192.168.1.33 now
motor ramp rates can/should be tweaked
lighting should be broken out into the three zones in software and we should get direction about what colors/effects to program
and the teensy with ethernet shield needs to be set up
I'd like to get a sense of current draw and heat produced when cubby is open
helpful
what of all of that were you planning/are best suited to do?
probably do first item first hopefully leave lighting and teensy to peter or joel
ramp rate and heat are bonus
agreed

josh two priorities for you are both or today <@U02F8LF2X> Goldspike Kit: Integrate into the wall <https://trello.com/c/R6TACquV>
Goldspike Kit: Put motor on the network 192.168.1.33  <https://trello.com/c/qsWUwPla>
<@U0ML49XU0>: for the wire frames - im not seeing updates for cubbies. I might be crazy. Are there specifics areas i should be looking at??
ill come over
<@U0260V4K1>: and <@U02F9CXTL> as you have questiosn for ty tack em onto my response ot her email chain: ‘Updated wires'
<@U0ML49XU0>: I’ll get stuff on the network today (both LEDs and motor)
<@U02F8LF2X>: no need to work on motor on network, keep focus on the tarp and getting GS Kit into the wall.  thanks <@U02E3CRMA>
it’s part of getting the GS kit in the wall :simple_smile:

<@U0EL0GLEL>: if you stay focused on getting content up on the wall and refining how it’s displayed, I’ll have time this afternoon to get all the teensy/led/motor stuff together for GS+wall integration

i would imagine the motor on the door gets fairly warm if you leave it open. my experience from 3d printing using these motors has shown they do get toasty. which seems to be in line with the constant warning of not keeping them open iontank keeps saying. getting a base line of what that really means would be good to know. im sure heatsinks or something could be used if needed.
good points

i have a feeling they will be left open at some point either loading or cleaning, stuff like that. so i think that is important to understand. so where ever that fits in priority i agree that chewy should investigate
completely agree
<@U02E3CRMA>: <https://trello.com/c/qsWUwPla>
more on motor from reading about it yesterday and setting it up: it's a scheider electric mdrive smart motor with rs232/rs485 ethernet bridge
the default ip is set to 192.168.1.33 so I set my laptop's ip to 192.168.0.1/255.255.0.0 to talk to it
so far not a ton of heat: 5 degrees F above ambient after ~20mins of holding open. this is the rear casing of the motor (I believe): pretty much the only thing I can measure
7 degrees. I am not very concerned
if the temp increase over that timeframe is so limited, why the warning from IonTank
is it purely a duty cycle concern
not sure. we're going to ask for a mechanical sketch to make sure I'm measuring the right thing

interesting, i know the motors on my printer after using it for a few hours get really quite hot with just ambient cooling. but they are active and not just sitting there holding current. I would imagine that the active motors would be much hotter. Is the concern more of ruining the motor? from what I have read about these motors they dont die very easily. and are extremely simple in design. These temps dont feel that concerning
motor is rated to 75C or 167F. I guess beyond that point insulation begins to melt or bearing grease ceases to lubricate properly?
I can try another test where I cycle the motor repeatedly and measure temp rise... time allowing
what are the net results thus far <@U02F8LF2X>  2 + hours, 10 degree?
2.5 hours 15.5 degrees
word
im cool concluding the test
get it, ‘cool’?  it’s a thermal test joke
(<@U02E3CRMA> pun alert)
